trial_identification.studytitle: Weight Loss in Overweight Women Study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Comparision of a red to white meat based diet on weight loss, body composition, metabolic and immune function in overweight young (18-25 year old) women
trial_identification.secondaryid: Efficacy of a higher-protein compared to a higher-carbohydrate diet for weight management in young overweight and obese women: a 12 month randomized controlled trial

interventions.interventions:
Prescription of either one of the two diets through randomisation. The two diets involve iso-energetic, low fat, low glycaemic index (GI) diets that differ in carbohydrate (glycaemic load) and protein content as well as red and white meat content. This involves a daily diet change for a total of 12 months.
All subjects (regardless of which diet they are assigned) will be asked to complete a minimum of 30 minutes light exercise on most days of the week.
interventions.comparator:
A high carbohydrate (glycaemic load), moderate protein diet that is mostly based on white meat. Subjects will be asked to follow this diet daily for 12 months.
It differs from the intervention group in that the other diet involves a moderate carbohydrate (glycaemic load), high protein diet that is mostly based on red meat.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Weight loss through the use of scales
Body fat loss through the use of: 1. Bioelectrical Impedance Analysis (BIA) 2. Dual-energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Improved immune function through the use of: 1. Blood test (e.g. testing of immune and inflammatory markers) 2. health log (log of subjective health throughout the 12 months of the trial) 3. Infection Visual Analogue scale (a subjective measurement of general health)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Young women Body Mass Index (BMI) >27.5 kg/m2
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Smokers, iron deficiency, diabetes (I or II), severe eating disorders, depression or medication influencing metabolism

trial_design.designfeatures: The glycaemic load of the diets are different but this is not disclosed to the study participants but is known by the investigators

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Discipline of Exercise and Sport Science University of Sydney PO BOX 170 Lidcombe 1825 Australia

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Level 1 165 Walker St North Sydney 2060 NSW

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Metabolism and Obesity Services Royal Prince Alfred Hospital Level 6 E Block Missenden Rd Camperdown NSW 2050 Australia

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
Comparison of higher protein, moderate carbohydrate red meat based Total Wellbeing diet versus iso-energetic, conventional, low fat, high carbohydrate diet on weight loss, immune function, satiety, metabolic parameters and iron status in young, overweight and obese women.
Research Hypothesis: A higher protein, red meat based diet for weight management in overweight and obese young women will improve satiety, eating behaviours, markers of immune function and metabolic parameters when compared to an iso-energetic higher carbohydrate, white meat based diet.
